body_content.explanation: someone who was on the side of the House of York during the English Wars of the Roses (1455–1487), fought between the Houses of Lancaster and York:
examples: Henry VII married Elizabeth of York to heal the rift between the Yorkists and Lancastrians.
Richard Duke of York was hailed by Yorkists as a legitimate pretender to the English throne.

body_content.explanation: belonging or relating to the side of the House of York during the English Wars of the Roses (1455–1487) fought between the Houses of Lancaster and York:
examples: The dispute had its origins in the battle of Wakefield, at which Sir Thomas Harrington of Hornby was killed on the Yorkist side.
A Lancastrian through his mother's descent from John of Gaunt, Henry VII reconciled the Yorkist faction by marrying Edward IV's daughter Elizabeth.
